results.title: Steam alive in Victoria: a tribute to steam
results.brief_description: The history of Victoria’s steam trains runs parallel to the history of the state itself. As the railway tracks made their way into the countryside, the state began to develop. Steam locomotives puffing their way into country towns were the life blood of the state, bringing in supplies and visitors and taking away produce and goods. Today the steam locomotives have been replaced. Many were left to rust and decay but a number of them have been restored by dedicated groups of volunteers, determined to preserve this exciting part of our heritage. Steam trains are alive again in Victoria and this magnificent videotape is a tribute to those groups who have kept the locomotives on the tracks to give pleasure to those who love steam travel. You can enjoy the thrill of the journey, the heat of the firebox and the shrill of the whistle as you watch “Steam Alive in Victoria”.

results.title: Steam across the mountains: the story of the Zig Zag Railway
results.creator_credit: Nick A'Hern, ABC Video and Nick A'Hern Productions
results.brief_description: The Zig Zag Railway is regarded as an engineering marvel and a mecca to students of engineering the world over. This fascinating video follows the Zig Zag’s colourful history from its early days in the great commercial steam era, to its closure in 1910 and through to its restoration as a tourist railway in 1975. This program uses the Zig Zag Railway as a working model to bring to life the romance adventure and style of the Great Australian Steam Era. Highlights include: complete stereo soundtrack, breathtaking footage shot entirely on 16mm film and loads of steam trains to see and hear!
results.title_for_label: Steam across the mountains: the story of the Zig Zag Railway
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nick A’Hern, ABC Video and Nick A’Hern Productions

results.title: Starstruck
results.creator_credit: Claude Kerven, Patrick McCormick and Highgate Pictures
results.brief_description: Depicts the conflicts faced by an adolescent girl who must choose between her dream to be a singer-song writer or living up to her mother’s hopes by following a secure but not totally satisfying career as a bookkeeper. This film would be useful for discussion of values, decision making and communication. Cast includes Trini Alvarado, Joanna Merlin. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Staying upfront
results.creator_credit: Stephen Ramsey, Michael Rubetzki and Film Australia
results.brief_description: This is a film about a long distance owner truck driver and his family. The reasons why he became an owner-driver are explored as well as the rewards he gets from it, and the effect on his family of operating in a high pressure, often marginal income industry.

results.title: Staying alive show (episodes 1, 2 & 3)
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Orr, Lyndall Horton-Jones, David Ferris and Healthsharing Women. Publishing and Production Group
results.brief_description: An entertaining video which reinforces the traffic safety message for children in the early to middle primary years. Using the format of a popular TV game show, contestants are qizzed on the do’s and don’ts of pedestrian and passenger safety.

results.title: Status = Status anxiety
results.creator_credit: James Runcie, Neil Crombie and Channel Four Television Corporation
results.brief_description: Alain de Botton presents this three-part documentary series which is an exploration of the modern dilemma of how work and objects define a person’s status in western society. Are we cash rich but spiritually poor? Does wealth equate to happiness? Why do we worry so much about what people think of us? Alain de Botton has a interesting take on this resulting in thought provoking television through the use of contemporary interviews mixed with some views of ancient philosophers brought into the contemporary context. He also talks to people with an alternative view, such as naturists and bohemians, to find out their understanding of ‘status’. Another interesting series by the same presenter is “Philosophy: a guide to happiness” [318970]. Written by Alain de Botton.

results.title: Stations
results.brief_description: A story, set in Brisbane in 1953, about a young woman who falls in love and becomes pregnant. What follows is a painful and deliberate account of women’s resilience in the face of the dilemmas and social constraints of Australia in the fifties. Stars Noni Hazelhurst and Tim Burns.

results.title: Station in life
results.creator_credit: John Gordon, Frank Torley and Television New Zealand
results.brief_description: Shows some of the daily activities on a sheep property in the New Zealand high country. Notes the effect of the climate on the husbandry practices at this station and the changes in land use due to soil erosion.

results.title: I am not alone
